title: 114_hr470
content: The "Chattahoochee-Oconee National Forest Land Adjustment Act of 2015" allows for the disposal of isolated National Forest System land in Georgia to be used for more efficient purposes. Proceeds from land sales will be used by the Forest Service to acquire land for National Forest purposes in the state. The term "Secretary" in the Act refers to the Secretary of Agriculture. The Secretary is authorized to sell or exchange United States' rights in National Forest System land in Georgia. The land subject to disposal consists of 30 tracts totaling 3,841 acres, depicted on maps dated September 24, 2013. The maps are available for public inspection at the Forest Supervisor's Office. The Forest Supervisor may modify boundaries based on land management considerations. Land sold under this Act will be conveyed by quitclaim deed, with reservations for necessary rights. The Secretary must sell or exchange land for at least market value, determined by appraisal or competitive bid. Appraisal requirements for land sales must adhere to specific standards and be approved by the Secretary. Consideration for sales must be paid in cash, and the Secretary has the authority to accept cash payments exceeding 25% of the land value in exchanges. The Secretary can sell land through various methods, including public or private sales, auctions, or competitive bids. The Secretary has the authority to sell land through public or private solicitations, auctions, or competitive bids. Brokers or third parties can be used in the land disposition process, with commissions or fees paid from sale proceeds. The Secretary deposits sale proceeds in the Sisk Act fund for land acquisition in Georgia. Funds can be used with owner consent only.
